comment_text: I’ve come back to this video a million times over the years and still wondered, why the hell didn’t he give it back to the local tribe or the descendants? If he’s so smart and able to figure out where it’s from, I feel like he can at least follow the basic guidelines of NAGPRA and make sure that the artifact goes back to the rightful owners. Would have saved him 2 weeks of walking. Oh but that wouldn’t make for a romantic story about the earth reclaiming the artifact, because modern day Native Americans don’t deserve the same respect that a remnant of their ancestors does.

This basically amounts to a "I'm so cool" story.
It's little more than an elaborate set-up for some imagined future prank.
If the story is even true, (Craig Childs is after all an author and creator of stories), his actions are just as reckless as those he condemned for possessing the pots. The pot, if ever found, will be discovered in a location that would ultimately create historic and geographical errors about the people and culture that created it. It's odd that he felt the need to take it upon himself to steal and (randomly) "return" the pot to the canyons, based on little more than his assumptions on how the pot came to be on display in the first place. Sure, he questions his actions, but he went ahead with them anyway.
Such a good collaboration! Two of my favourite things on the interwebs!

Isn't pottery the throwaway plastic of the past? There's so much of the stuff lying around, and of course archeologists can learn a lot from them, but once they have some to study the rest are useless to science (as long as it isn't a previously undiscovered model), so there's no harm in "stealing" them.
At the same time, I think stealing one back and re-burying it will be valuable to future archeologists, they'll be able to learn a lot about us from the fact that we took an ancient, broken vase, "fixed" it with tape and put it back.

Using the drawings in this video, I located the pot you stole and returned it to the Salado people. They saw the tape and glue and have declared me their new god. I will return the pot to where you left it in exchange for a handful of glass beads and some blankets. If you need to contact me, you can tune your radio to 1.21 gigawatts. That is all.

"IT BELONGS IN A MUSEUM"
- Indiana Jones

Sometimes the value of an object stops being about "how many dollars I can get if I sell it to a collector", and transcends to "How can we keep this from ever disappearing so that we have a memory of history and the people who used to be here". Where I live, if you find a significant piece of archeological treasure, you are rewarded by the state for handing it in to the proper authorities so that it may be studied and preserved. You could probably sell such an item for much more, but it would not serve the same purpose.
It's probably illegal to dig for old pots with the intention of keeping them, or selling them, for the reason that you would much rather have those pots be publicly available for future generations to see, or hear about. Even the ones that aren't displayed in a museum help contribute to the research that helps tell the story of the people who made them.

This isn't a minute physics video, not in subject, nor in style or quality.

Although the subject is intriguing, the quality of the production is pretty lousy compared to other minute physics videos. I have a lot of respect for you and your usual quality of your work, but this isn't in the same league.

We start with the usual favourite narrator and then a guest, which is a new feature, and then again an additional narrator, whom subscribers to minute physics likely don't know. From there, the the audio progresses slowly, with many gaps, as the three people talk about archeology.

Perhaps this should have been uploaded to a different channel and then recommended at the end of a minute physics video. I'm surprised that so many people "liked" it. I guess it's the idea of this guy stealing back pottery and then burying that's so out-of-the-norm that you get likes for that reason.

If it was any random YouTuber, then I wouldn't complain. Your usual style and overall quality of presentation leads to expectations of the same. I hope you are able to tell that I am a fan, and I'm sure that you know how critical fans can be. What I mean to say is that I love your videos. If you had put this on a different channel so that we wouldn't have expect that same style and quality, then I wouldn't have complained.

This was so wrong.
You should have given it to a museum, or the native inhabitants.  Someone's just going to steal it again, probably damage it even further.
By artificially putting it back into the ground, to pretend it was never moved or handled, aren't you commiting a scientific fraud?  If anthropologists do find it again centuries from now (given the rate of pillaging currently i give it a max of 1-2 decades), they will wrongly assume it's in it's original burial place and will wrongly catalog it as such.
What if you have fucked up our understanding of this extinct culture?  "They buried things in cliffs, we have evidence".

Yeah, i also hope the tape survives long enough to give away the real story to whoever finds it.  But you have to ask yourself: what was the fucking point. 
- Either someone steals it again, possibly damaging it further, sells it, further funding their horrid industry.
- Or a scientist finds it, with tape on it, concludes it's been planted/tainted/moved/faked, and it's thus of little-to-no use to the scientific community.
- Or a scientist finds it, and catalogs it as real, (the tape perhaps having been blown away).  Then when the pot is analysed at a later date, evidence of it's strange journey shows up, and we conclude fucked up things like "ancient people invented tape - to secure pots into cliffs".

Wow, if you just stole the pot to 'punish' the people who had bought it illegally, that would be one thing, but what you did was actually worse. Most of the original scientific value of the pot was lost when it was dug up without being properly documented, but putting it in some random hole in the rock could destroy some future archeologist's career. Imagine some poor schmuck who finds it and sends it back to the university (or wherever) for analysis. If you're wondering to yourself "why does it matter that non-experts steal artifacts", it all has to do with CONTEXT. Context means everything. An archaeologist can learn things about an object by seeing how it is related to its surroundings. For example, in an ancient Egyptian tomb objects placed with the dead often have personal meaning to the deceased, and from these objects you can recreate the life of the deceased and then from there figure out societal contexts like rites of passage, status and religious symbols, family structure, hierarchies etc. You can't get this context if the object is removed from its natural habitat. Objects give you sense of "what". Context gives you a sense of when, where, how, and why.
Removing context to an archaeologist is like forcing someone to read a book in a foreign language they don't understand with no means of translation.

This isn't a valiant correction of thievery, this is just plain stealing. It may not seem that way, but consider this:

The original owners are dead. The pot was discarded in the dirt. There's no information on who owned the dirt so I assume it wasn't owned. If that's the case, then these people provided a service by finding the pot and displaying it, you should pay them if you want it; but less so if they broke it, to incentivize proper care. If the land was owned, then that information is the important key in unlocking the legal mechanism in which the pot can be returned to it's rightful owner.

Also, returning the pot to the dirt isn't progress.

A really profound (and funny) story, but I have to agree with many other commenters that this is not the right channel for this type of content. People who have subscribed to a channel called "MinutePhysics" obviously expect to get physics-related videos from that channel, and when that isn't the case and there is no explanation for it, they have a right to be upset, in my opinion. Again, I loved the video, but this is not the right channel for it.
Person being interviewed, you truly have made this earth a better place for everyone with your selfless crusade against injustice. EVERYTHING PRECEDING THIS IS SARCASM What a waste of a video.

I liked the concept of hearing somebody's interesting story with your animation style, but it certainly doesn't fit on this channel. If you plan on doing more, you could do a MinuteTalks (sorry, bad at making names) channel. I would honestly subscribe to it, but I don't know about anybody else though.
When people dig up pots it is illegal but when an archaeologist does it it's legal. How come?

So... no offense, but this guy is an idiot!  He thinks he's g.d. Indiana Jones, except instead of saying, "it belongs in a museum!", he thinks it belongs in a hole in a frickin' cliff?  What the what???

Oh yeah, it's such a travesty that these artifacts are being dug up out of the ground and put in private collections.  I know, let's go put them back in the ground where they can pretty much rot and be destroyed by rain and sun and erosion!  Sound like a great way to "preserve history"?

I was totally expecting him to say he took it to a museum where it was properly catalogued, labeled and displayed for all to see and enjoy.  And instead... oh, man, I'm just repeating myself, but gaaaaahhh!  I just can't stand the stupidity and self-righteousness!
Why aren't the pots allowed to be taken? And what gives this pot theft the right to break in?
